posts.name: Stephen Kalogiannis
posts.cooked: Looking for some help on achieving something I have been playing with in SolidWorks for a few weeks now. At the component level I have it working the way I want it to. I have a file property called Hole Diameter, where I can input a value and the diameter changes with the click of the rebuild button. In the assembly I have multiple different components using the hole diameter to define its dimension, what I would like to do is within the assembly file properties use a callout similar to what I do on the component level and have all the derived dimensions change with the click of the rebuild button. Currently the only way I have been able to do it is to go into each individual component and change its file properties dimension to the new hole diameter. This seems to be because the component is always calling back to the components file properties rather than the assemblies file properties.

posts.name: Rachael Naoum
posts.cooked: This is actually something I did in college for my senior design project. The technique I used involved creating a text file with global variables linked to my model. Here are some useful resources: an article from GoEngineer discussing linking values with external files in SolidWorks, a SOLIDWORKS VAR, and a YouTube video explaining the process. My senior design project paper, available in Appendix D, includes this text file along with the model, allowing you to review the setup.

How to Link Values with External Files in SOLIDWORKS | GoEngineer

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: I highly recommend a separate global variable file. When working with tabs, slots, or plywood construction, you can model everything with a nominal thickness and router bit, updating the models easily once you measure the actual material thickness or when switching cutters. This approach is generally very useful when starting modeling before finalizing all measurements.

posts.name: Stephen Kalogiannis
posts.cooked: Thank you for your reply! This is exactly what I was looking for. This has held me up on a project I have been working on for a few weeks now. So very much appreciated.

posts.name: Frank Lima
posts.cooked: Another technique is called "master modeling." This Old Tony has an educational and entertaining video about master modeling. TLDW: Create a master part consisting of sketches of the critical or shared geometry. Import that master part into each subsidiary part you're designing and reference the subsidiary parts off the master sketches. Thus, enabling multiple parts to easily share parametric geometry.

posts.name: Stephen Kalogiannis
posts.cooked: To add onto this, can you create equations and drive configuration selections within an assembly? For instance, I have an assembly containing a part with four different configurations defined by the depth of a hole—9mm, 8mm, 7mm, and 6mm. My goal is to use material thickness as a global variable to automatically select the appropriate configuration based on the inputted material thickness value. Currently, I'm using an equation such as =IF("materialthickness" < 3, 9mm, 8mm), which works to some extent but results in losing the configuration names since these represent different blanks available in the assembly. When setting up a Bill of Materials (BOM), the incorrect blank is selected because the equation modifies the hole depth rather than simply switching configurations. Ideally, I want a method that allows me to directly reference the correct configuration name based on the material thickness input. Hopefully, this clarifies my requirements.

posts.name: Rachael Naoum
posts.cooked:
I am not aware of any method of using equations to insert a specific component into an assembly Unfortunately For your case here I would recommend creating configurations of the assembly and then changing the configuration of the part in each assembly configuration So in your example you would have 4 assembly configurations using a different configuration of that part in each of them  

Without knowing much about your specific model I would say you can probably use equations mates or other constraints in such a way that they will intentionally fail when not using the correct configuration This will tell you the designer that you should try a different configuration Though that might just be extra work especially if you've already created different assembly configurations manually  

Hope this helps

posts.name: Frank Lima
posts.cooked: Extremely importantly, do not output anything but the cleaned version (no introduction, no other little explanation), just the cleaned paragraph.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: Before we switched to Onshape 3512, we got really good at SolidWorks Master sketching. This is our 2022 bot. We have assembled a variety of components including a Drivetrain, Intake, Conveyor, Shooter, Climber, and Eboard. Each of these parts has been designed and optimized for performance. The Drivetrain system uses a 6-gear reduction setup to achieve high torque transfer. The Intake component ensures efficient airflow, while the Conveyor system handles material transport efficiently. The Shooter module is equipped with precision, and the Climber utilizes advanced mechanisms for vertical movement. The Eboard system supports electronic connectivity. Together, these components form a complete solution tailored for our operations.
